content: You need to contact your email provider to get your password. Once you get it and enter at a Thunderbird prompt, Thunderbird will retain it for future logins.
creator: davidsk

content: Press Alt-e and choose Account Settings from the drop-down menu that appears. At the bottom of the left-hand column of the screen that opens is am "Account Actions" button. Click that then Add Mail Account.
creator: thepillenwerfer

content: Email accounts need to have server names for input and output, port numbers for each, connection and authentication for each, plus your email address and password. If your email account is with a popular email provider, such as Gmail or Outlook, Thunderbird will already have all the information needed, other than your email address and password. If your email address is not common, your email provider can provide the details mentioned here.
creator: davidsk

content:
Please note: if Thunderbird is closed - not running - then any messages that are received by the server are not downloaded. It's impossible to download anything if Thunderbird is not running. They just collect in your account on the server.

When you start Thunderbird, connection is made to server and then download occurs. So all emails received by server can only be downloaded when Thunderbird is connected to the internet.

I presume those emails are then looking wrong when you open to read them

See if something has gone wrong with the index file - try this:

  • Right click on Inbox folder and select 'Properties'
  • Click on 'Repair Folder' button
  • click on 'OK'
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
First, if you have a suggestion for Thunderbird, please post it at https://connect.mozilla.org/ under IDEAS. Developers review suggestions there. This is a peer-to-peer help forum and we don't make those decisions.

Second, despite the narrow columns, you can still edit the password by using cursor to scroll left or right. And the 'copy password' copies the entire password, not just the characters displayed in the column.

content:
I'm presuming you mean the following:

In Thunderbird In 'Inbox' or any folder You have emails sorted by 'threaded' option. If those threads are in a collapsed state, you will see a > chevron to the left of the subject That means the original oldest email with chevron is one you see as it is top of the list. The chevron > means it has other currently hidden emails which are part of the same conversation - people were replying back and forth.

If you then click on the top level 'collapsed' 'threaded' email to open then you get a load of emails each opening in a new tab. This is not a new function - it has been around for well over a decade. Clicking on a collapsed thread has always been an instruction to open all threads in separate tabs.

If you click on the > chevron, then it expands the thread, so you now see indented all the separate emails listed. This allows you to click on the actual email you wanted to open.

If you do not want to use the 'threaded' option then switch it off.

  • Select the Inbox folder in Folder Pane.
  • Using 'Menu Bar'
  • 'View' > 'Sort by' >select 'unthreaded'

If you cannot see the 'Menu bar' (File, Edit, View, etc)

  • Click on Menu app icon (3 lines)
  • 'View' > 'Toolbar' > select 'Menu bar'
creator: Toad-Hall
